instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Charging Battery - Battery Detected
threads.message:
Hello guys,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> running perfectly fine except that it doesn't want to charge the battery or run off the battery. Battery is detected and charging symbol shows.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13.1v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> pins 1,2,3 (<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHR_R</SIGNAL>) = 13.1v
pin 4 (BGATE) = 13.1v
pins 5,6,7,8 = 11.6v

When MacBook lid is closed, amps being pulled from charger is only 0.01. I tried existing battery as well as new battery. Same behaviour except the existing one is stuck at 1% and the 0% for the new battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Charging Battery - Battery Detected
threads.message:
Battery screw correctly tight?
Did you try known good original (even old) battery?

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> on battery only?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Charging Battery - Battery Detected
threads.message:
Battery screwed tightly 100%. Without the charger connected, old battery shows 2v (most likely because it's dead and hasn't been charging) and new battery shows 11.5v.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present with battery only only if new battery is put in. Old battery is probably just dead.

How do AMON/BMON signals work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Charging Battery - Battery Detected
threads.message:
AMON/BMON report current passing through <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>/60 respectively.

I will not trust new chinese battery, if is the case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Not Charging Battery - Battery Detected
threads.message:
I am not too sure what happened, but the ISL <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> got reflowed and it started working. Didn't see any signs of corrosion here, but it did the job.

Unfortunately, I don't have too many reliable suppliers for batteries... mostly Amazon. :/
